metadata.synopsis: Astarion returns to camp after being scratched up by a bear. He's not badly hurt, but feels invigorated - almost drunk - after drinking the beast's blood.

45.speaker: Astarion
45.context: NodeContext: Limping towards the player, but very happy - almost drunk

60.speaker: Astarion
60.text: Are you now? Don't make promises you can't keep, darling.

28.speaker: Astarion
28.text: Thankfully I've had my needs met this evening. I found a bear.

3.speaker: Astarion
3.text: He took a little of my blood, I took all of his.

19.speaker: Player
19.text: Where did you find a bear down here?

11.speaker: Astarion
11.text: I mean - I think it was a bear? Big head, four legs, hair that gets stuck in your teeth.

31.speaker: Astarion
31.text: Whatever it was, I thoroughly enjoyed it.

10.speaker: Astarion
10.text: It's nothing compared to - well, other things I could be dining on. But significantly better than the rats and bugs Cazador served me.

25.speaker: Player
25.text: You seem happy. No need to drink humanoid blood, then?

30.speaker: Astarion
30.text: You're comparing plonk to vintage wine. You can make merry with either, but they are not the same.

27.speaker: Astarion
27.text: But Cazador fed me rats and bugs. And when you're used to drinking from a sewer, even plonk is a marked improvement.

33.speaker: Player
33.text: As long as you're leaving mine alone.

14.speaker: Astarion
14.text: You think I'd kill you, just like that? Darling, I would never!

15.speaker: Astarion
15.text: Anyway, the bear will sustain me. And it's a marked improvement over the rats and flies Cazador would feed me.

4.speaker: Astarion
4.text: It was exactly as appetising as you'd think.

18.speaker: Player
18.text: Does it matter? Blood is blood, isn't it?

49.speaker: Astarion
49.text: Not at all! Blood is life essence. And some creatures have so much more life than others.

0.speaker: Astarion
0.text: Cazador gave me just enough to keep me - well, 'alive', for lack of a better word. But never more than that.

38.speaker: Astarion
38.text: Still, that was the past. I'll never have to grovel for him again.

50.speaker: Player
50.text: True, you can start over. You can be better than what he made you.

13.speaker: Astarion
13.text: Exactly! I can be better than him. Stronger. More powerful. More -

37.speaker: Astarion
37.text: - oh, you meant 'be kinder'? Pet bunnies, that sort of thing?

59.speaker: Astarion
59.text: I've no objection to being nice, of course. Once I have the power to bend others to my will.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: Maybe not, but you'll grovel before the mind flayers if you keep using the tadpole.

24.speaker: Astarion
24.text: I don't intend to grovel before anyone!

63.speaker: Astarion
63.text: The mind flayers gave us power, but left us to our own devices. Whatever they had planned for us, they failed.

26.speaker: Astarion
26.text: And now I'm left with this gift: the strength to take my own freedom. I'm not afraid to use it, and you shouldn't be either.

42.speaker: Astarion
42.text: Well - look at us. We've never been more powerful.

22.speaker: Astarion
22.text: And being able to walk in the sunlight opens a lot of doors for me. Maybe some coffins too.

16.speaker: Astarion
16.text: No, these tadpoles are a gift I intend to use to the fullest. You should do the same.

6.speaker: Player
6.text: Rats? And what did you do to deserve that?

32.speaker: Astarion
32.text: I existed, that was enough for him. He revelled in having power over me.

41.speaker: Astarion
41.text: Because those with power can do whatever the hell they want.

52.speaker: Player
52.text: You think power lets you do anything, free from consequences?

8.speaker: Astarion
8.context: NodeContext: response to "you think power lets you do whatever you want?"

43.speaker: Astarion
43.text: You can't look at the world and tell me I'm wrong.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: You're free now. That's what matters.

51.speaker: Astarion
51.text: Is it? What good is freedom if I'm always watching the shadows?

39.speaker: Astarion
39.text: No, I'll be safe when I'm powerful enough to grind Cazador into the dust. Powerful enough to do whatever the hell I want.

61.speaker: Player
61.text: The strong have a duty to protect the weak.

53.speaker: Astarion
53.text: They're doing a piss poor job, then.

7.speaker: Astarion
7.text: The strong had two centuries to pluck me from torture, but no one came. No, it was the mind flayers that rescued me.

29.speaker: Astarion
29.text: They gave me a gift: the strength to take my own freedom. I'm embracing this power - you should too.
29.context: NodeContext: last line: with a little relish

2.speaker: Player
2.text: Power corrupts. You'd do well to remember that.

54.speaker: Astarion
54.text: Oh I hope so. A little corruption sounds fun.

9.speaker: Astarion
9.text: I spent centuries as the victim of a corrupt man. It was the mind flayers that plucked me away from that.

55.speaker: Player
55.text: Careful, there are heroes about. I'd hate for them to get the right idea about you.

57.speaker: Astarion
57.text: Let them. Heroes are half the damn problem. Fools that believe in right and wrong - good and evil.

12.speaker: Astarion
12.text: Heroes didn't save me from Cazador: mind flayers did.

5.speaker: Player
5.text: We're not powerless. The tadpoles are quite the asset.

46.speaker: Astarion
46.text: Indeed they are. Now that I can walk in the sun - well, that opens all manner of doors.

56.speaker: Astarion
56.text: It could open some coffins too.

40.speaker: Astarion
40.text: Oh, that. A scratch. I ran afoul of a bear.

62.speaker: Astarion
62.text: I have drunk. Not alcohol, of course. A bear.
